- Prefer Julia standard libraries, avoid new packages unless explicitly requested.

# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is how you can solve this problem in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # filter down the dataset to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4 or a4 quattro"
    df_filtered = @from i in df_cars begin
        where (:manufacturer == "Audi") & ((:model == "A4") | (:model == "A4 Quattro"))
    end
    
    # create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals true across all rows
    df_filtered[:audi_a4_type] = true
    
    return df_filtered
end
```
This function uses the `@from` macro from DataFrames.jl to filter the dataframe based on manufacturer and model, then adds a new column `audi_a4_type` that is always `true`. 

Please note that this solution assumes that your columns are case-sensitive (i.e., "Audi" not "audi"). If you want to make it case-insensitive, you can modify the filter condition like so: `(lowercase(:manufacturer) == "audi") & ((:model == "a4") | (:model == "a4 quattro"))`.
